newsitem.title: UK: Short-termism - Is it choking British industry?.
newsitem.headline: Short-termism - Is it choking British industry?.

text.p: Britain's industrial leaders have hotly refuted accusations that the UK financial system has damagingly short-term demands and hinders vital investment.
Leading UK employers group, the Institute of Directors, said the idea that Britain's financial system is riven with short-termism was a fallacy.
It noted the success of British pharmaceutical firms in recent years and the ease with which biotechnology firms have raised capital on the London Stock Exchange.

"This provides clear evidence of the ability and willingness of the UK's financial system to raise finance for investments whose returns may take many years to be realised," said IoD executive Stephen Davies.

The main charge of short-termism is that financial institutions, who hold share stakes in many of Britain's major companies, consistently demand high short-term returns -- large profits generating hefty dividend payouts.

Share buybacks are also a popular ploy. There, a company spends millions of pounds buying back its own stock to boost the share price, thus keeping hungry shareholders happy and warding off the attentions of potential takeover predators.

The short-termism debate was ignited last year by Will Hutton, editor of Britain's Observer newspaper and author of the best-selling book, "The State We're In". In it, he said the UK's economic performance was undermined by short-termism.
Be it high dividend payouts or share buybacks, capital that could be earmarked for much-needed investment, goes elsewhere. That, Hutton argued, is eating away Britain's industrial base.

Andrew Sentance, director of the London Business School's Centre for Economic Forecasting, said the pressure on managers to maximise short-term profits was probably greater in Britain than in other countries.
"If you talk to British managers, there is undoubtedly a perception of pressures on them to think more short-term than in other countries such as Germany and Japan."
He said an at-best average investment performance gave some credence to the allegation of short-termism but to blame that entirely on stock market attitudes was a leap too far.
The volatility of UK economic policy, leading to a "boom/bust" economy in the 1970s and 1980s, had made long-term strategy difficult for British companies, he said.
He also highlighted the incentive for managers holding stock options and similar bonuses to ensure their company's share price does not drop for any significant period of time.

Davies at the IoD chose to view Britain's average investment performance as more of a sign of success than failure. Taking the share of fixed investment in gross domestic product as a measure, he said Britain hovered about mid-table compared with its major industrial counterparts.
Most experts agreed that short-termism is there in certain guises but it has positive as well as negative influences.

"If a company is not generating profits short-term, the question would have to be whether it would long-term," Sentance said. "To some extent, the pressure from the City and elsewhere helps ensure levels of efficiency."

Ian Fletcher, policy executive at the British Chambers of Commerce, said financing problems may be more acute for smaller and medium-sized UK enterprises (SMEs) than for high flyers on the FTSE-100 index of leading firms.
There, potentially high-return ventures attract floods of capital, while the rest are ignored.

"For SMEs, expectations are very high, perhaps more so than for firms properly quoted on the stock market," Fletcher said. "Investments can double or triple quickly but they are the exception. Many firms find it hard to attract finance at all."

Even the IoD acknowledged smaller firms in Britain may have a tough time luring funds looking for a quick return. It said the UK had a less effective framework for solving the funding problems of smaller businesses than in other European countries.

But overall, it stuck to it's guns. Hutton's charge that the stock market system demands high returns from companies at the expense of investment is unfounded. "The truth is the opposite," Davies said. "UK industry has actually achieved relatively low profits compared with its competitors."
